msItem.title: Notes on lunar calculations for Easter
msItem.incipit: 1r Post primam luna Epiphaniam computa decem dies et in die sequente dominica claud[e]tur alleluia
msItem.explicit: 1r Post quintam prima computa iiiior dies et in dominica sequente erit pentecostis

msItem.title: Entries from a Latin vocabulary
msItem.note: Definitions of Latin words in Latin and English: Contaminor [...] polluor; Contaminor as to file; and Contemptor [...].

listBibl.bibl: Not included in the Index of Middle English Prose

msItem.title: Middle English translation of the Compendium urinarum
msItem.author: Walter Agilton
msItem.rubric: 2r Tractatus magistri bartholomei ordinis sancti francisci et composuit breuiter in lingua materna magis plane ad intelligenciam laicorum ad eos gubernandum prout placet altissimo ad requisicionem regis ricardi secundi et anne regine
msItem.incipit: 2r This boke that we haue now in hande to turne into englissh is of the craft of urines but whoo it is that werketh it we knowe not sauf onely god nathelesse we suppose and us thenketh therby it is a coment upon a text of urines that a worshepful doctor aboue rehersed seith this verified in latine
msItem.explicit: 25r and thus endeth these 18 contentes aftre 20 colours forsaid
msItem.note: The heading that names the translator as Master Bartholomew and the commissioners as Richard II and Queen Anne is apparently unique to this manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 222

msItem.title: Pro gomorea et spermate restringendo
msItem.incipit: 25r Recipe: pul. Mente. Agnicasti
msItem.explicit: 25v 1 muscate parum. fiat electuarum

msItem.title: Twenty-Jordans Uroscopy
msItem.textLang: Middle English treatise with Latin headings
msItem.rubric: 25v [H]ec sunt vrinarum signa cum medicinis sequentibus
msItem.incipit: 25v Urina ruffa colour of water as pure golde signifieth the emeroudes passing oute of the floures
msItem.explicit: 29r Medicina take poudre of Iete and of towne carse sede I brent and vse it in thie potage

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 223

msItem.title: Tract on uroscopy
msItem.incipit: 29r Urine Ruffe et subruffe Iste due significant digestionem
msItem.explicit: 29r Pallidus subpallidus Iste due significat principium digestionis

msItem.title: Tract on uroscopy
msItem.incipit: 29r Omnis vrina est colamentum sanguinis et est duarum rerum proprie signifficatiua
msItem.explicit: 29v Quarta est fundus . Per circulum egritudo capitis et cerebri [?] cognostitiuo
msItem.note: Also part of a treatise on urine edited in C. H. Talbot, 'A Mediaeval Physician's Vade Mecum', Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences, 16:3 (1961), 213-233 (pp. 226-227).

msItem.title: Poem on the Four Humours
msItem.rubric: 29v De quatuor complexionibus hominum et moribus eorundem
msItem.incipit: 29v Sangineus: [L]argus amans Ilaris ridens rubei que coloris
msItem.explicit: 30r Non expers fraudis tumidus lutei que coloris

msItem.title: Tractatus medicinarum omnium membrorum distemperatorum
msItem.textLang: Latin treatise with some Middle English
msItem.incipit: 30r Incipit breuis tractus [sic] et vtilis medicinarum omnium membrorum distemperatorum
msItem.explicit: 41r irabile est effectus
msItem.note: A Middle English recipe to treat the stomach occurs on f. 41r.

Other copies of this anonymous text appear to survive in: Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 6891, ff. 80v-82r; Paris, Bibliothèque Mazarine, MS 3599, ff. 69r-69v; and St Gallen, Kantonsbibliothek Vadianische Sammlung, MS 435, ff. 155r-156v.

msItem.title: Treatise on Uroscopy
msItem.incipit: 42r Prima ruffa significat salutum et bona disposicionem corporis
msItem.explicit: 47r Sub ruffus color vrine vt aurum remissum significat perfectam digestionem
msItem.note: The heading/rubric has been added by a later (16th-century) hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings
msItem.note: Collection of fourteen recipes, among which is an English version of the so-called Tres Boni Fratres charm for staunching blood on ff. 52v-53r (Medicina ad obturandum siue cessandum sanguinem).
Ends imperfectly with an unfinished recipe entitled: 'A medicine for Wodenesse'.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat the stone
Summa de formis electionum episcoporum faciendarum
msItem.author: Lawrence of Somercotes
msItem.incipit: 56r Omnibus Christi fidelibus sancte matris ecclesie filijs ad quos presens et scriptum peruenerit Laurencius de Somertoun domini pape subdiaconus Canonicus Cicestriensis gratiam
msItem.explicit: 75r Ibi eciam loquitur de formis et eleccionibus faciendis. Deo Gracias.

listBibl.bibl: Alfred von Wretschoko, Der Traktat des Laurentius de Somercote, Kanonikus von Chichester: über die Vornahme von Bischofswahlen entstanden im Jahre 1254 (Weimar: Böhlaus, 1907) [without this manuscript]

msItem.title: Regulae Juris
msItem.author: Boniface VIII
msItem.incipit: 76r Beneficium ecclesiasticum non potest licite sine institutione canonica optineri
msItem.explicit: 79r Certum est quod is committit in legem qui legis verba complectens contra legis nititur voluntatem

msItem.title: Proverbs of Seneca
msItem.author: Pseudo-Seneca the Younger
msItem.incipit: 80r [A]lienum est esse quod optando euenit
msItem.explicit: 89v Zelari hominibus viciosum est

msItem.title: De remediis fortuitorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Seneca the Younger
msItem.rubric: 90r Lucii Annei Senece ad Collionem de remediis fortuitorum malorum
msItem.incipit: 90r Licet cunctorum poetarum carmina ingenium nostrum semper illustrent aliquando deliberans hoc tibi opusculum
msItem.explicit: 97r ffelix est non qui alijs videtur sed qui sibi vides autem quam rara sit in aliqua domo ista felicitas
msItem.finalRubric: 97r Explicit scriptura Lucij Annei Senece ad callionem de remedijs fortuitorum malorum

msItem.title: Poem on the Four Humours
msItem.rubric: 97v Quatuor humores in homine secundum quatuor elumenta
msItem.incipit: 97v Quatuor humores in humano corpore constant
msItem.explicit: 98r Sanguine fit glaucus colera rubius quoque ruphus

msItem.title: Letter from Isabella of France concerning the bishop of Thérouanne, Chancellor of France
msItem.incipit: 98v Ysabel par la grace de dieu Royne de ffrance
msItem.explicit: 99r Escript a paris le xxvme Jour de Septembre

msItem.title: Letter by the Duchess of Burgundy to Henry Beaufort, Bishop of Winchester, on behalf of the Sieur de Bussy taken prisoner by Rodrigo de Villandando, 13 September 1430
msItem.rubric: 99r Tresreuerend pere en dieu et nostre trescher et tresame cousin le cardinal de Winchestre
msItem.incipit: 99r Tresreuerend pere en dieu mon trescher et tresame oncle trescordialment et humblement je me recommaunde tousiours a vous
msItem.explicit: 100r Escript a anvers le xiijme Jour de Septembre
msItem.finalRubric: 100r Vostre niepce la duchesse de Bourgoigne et de Braub[ant]

msItem.title: Unfinished letter to a cardinal of England (probably Henry Beaufort)
msItem.rubric: 100r Tresreuerend pere en dieu le cardinal dangleterre mon trescher et tresame oncle

msItem.title: La Maniere de langage [Dialogue with lines alternately in French and English]
msItem.incipit: 100v Ditez Fuisse je savement aler / Saie may I saufly good
msItem.explicit: 106v Dame bon your auez vouz / DAme good daie haue ye

msItem.title: Council of Darius to Alexander the Great
msItem.incipit: 107r Alexander fili vt plenus tua nouit sapiencia totus mundus in corrupcione consistit
msItem.explicit: 108v Sed eciam pro pietate Alexandri et sepelierunt cum reuersus est itaque ad Regale palacium Alexander

msItem.title: Wisdom of Alexander the Great
msItem.rubric: 109r Sapiencia Alexandri quando precepit subditis suis se parare quod pugnam
msItem.incipit: 109r Alexander pro tribunali in solio patris sui sedens congregata populi multitudine taliter est affactus viri macedon seu greci intuemini Alexandrum
msItem.explicit: 109v hoc eo dicente omnes eius sapienciam laudauerunt et eius dictis prudentissime acquieuerunt

msItem.title: Epitaph of Alexander the Great
msItem.incipit: 109v En ego qui totum mundum certamine vici
msItem.explicit: 110r Quis sum et qualis lector et ipse vides

msItem.title: Tract on Alexander's vices
msItem.incipit: 110v Alexander iste qui magnas puer dicitur licet
msItem.explicit: 110v nunquam curari possunt vnde dixit per suis [...] succurrite morbo etcaetera

msItem.title: Somniale Danielis
msItem.rubric: 112r Ego sum Daniel unus de filiis Israel qui captivi ducti sunt de ierusalem in babilonem hec omnia a domino cepi et nihil de meo ipso addidi
msItem.incipit: 112r Anima tractare mutacionem significat
msItem.explicit: 117v Manus suas ligatas videre damnum significat

supportDesc.support: Parchment (ff. 1, 28, 29, 55-117) (FHHF); and paper, folded in octavo. Mount in a circle ( 150 110 ) in the left upper margin of the folio

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

list.item: Quire 228-1 (ff. 29-55: 27th leaf, after f. 54, excised; perhaps blank)
Quire 88-2 (ff. 112-117: 7th and 8th leaves, after f. 117, missing)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink written in the right-hand lower corner of last versos.

supportDesc.condition: One excised leaf after f. 54 has been replaced with blank paper; damage to the outer margin of ff. 100-117 and to the left-hand upper margin of ff. 114-117 has been repaired with blank parchment.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 18-25 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in various cursive hands with features of Anglicana, Secretary, and lettre batarde.

decoNote.p: Three-line red initial with pen-flourishing in black and red ink on f. 2r; and five-line initial in black ink with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in black ink on f. 56r.
Guide-letters and small (one-line) capitals occasionally highlighted in red ink.
Cadels in black ink attached to ascenders on the top lines and capitals.

note.p: Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink, c. 1958 (inside lower cover).

binding.p: Brown quarter leather with marbled paper sides. Bound by W.H. Smith and Son, London, June 1958 according to an inscription on the inside upper cover. Classmark labels from the previous spine have been pasted on the inside upper cover.

origin.origDate: Written in the late 15th century or first half of the 16th century

provenance.p: Rychard Lorans Lorans, Rychard : his name inscribed in a late 15th- or early 16th-century script in the lower margin of 34r: 'Rychard Lorans', perhaps with another personal name: '? Ambrose Amare'.
John Kyngsouth (?) Kyngsouth (?), John : his name inscribed in a late 15th- or early 16th-century script in the lower margin of 35r: 'John Kyng[?sou]th'.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 217 (inscribed in ink on f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on f. inside of the upper cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on This catalogue entry draws on M. Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74). The description of the watermark has been sourced from a database of paper-stocks compiled by Dr Orietta da Rold and is reproduced here by her kind permission.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
